natural problem: My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose?
natural solution: First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "k = 11"
shows  "fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)) = 48048"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "k = 11"
shows  "fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)) = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the number of combinations when choosing 11 items out of 16. The final answer is 48,048.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r g :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "r = 10"
and h2 : "g = 1"
and h3 : "choose n (r + g) = 48048"
shows  "choose 16 11 = 48048"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes n r g :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "r = 10"
and h2 : "g = 1"
and h3 : "choose n (r + g) = 48048"
shows  "choose 16 11 = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a set of 16 items, how many ways are there to choose 11 items considering 10 red and 1 green item? The final answer is 48,048.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "k = 11"
shows  "n choose k = 48048"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "k = 11"
shows  "n choose k = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the value of the binomial coefficient $\binom{16}{11}$. The final answer is 48,048.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n r. C n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "n = 16"
and h2 : "r = 11"
shows  "C n r = 48048"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes n r :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n r. C n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "n = 16"
and h2 : "r = 11"
shows  "C n r = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the number of combinations of 16 items taken 11 at a time, where the combination formula is given by $C(n, r) = \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$. The final answer is 48,048.

fixes n r :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "r = 11"
and h2 : "lineup = n choose r"
shows  "lineup = 48048"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048

The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes n r lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 16"
and h1 : "r = 11"
and h2 : "lineup = n choose r"
shows  "lineup = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the number of ways to choose 11 players from a team of 16 players. The final answer is 48,048.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes starting_lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "starting_lineup = choose 15 10"
shows  "starting_lineup = 48048"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes starting_lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "starting_lineup = choose 15 10"
shows  "starting_lineup = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many ways can you choose a starting lineup of 10 players from a pool of 15 players? The final answer is 48,048.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes players :: nat and starting_lineup :: nat and goalie :: nat
assumes h0 : "players = 16"
and h1 : "starting_lineup = 10"
and h2 : "goalie = 1"
shows  "n_choose_k (players - goalie) starting_lineup = 48048"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes players :: nat and starting_lineup :: nat and goalie :: nat
assumes h0 : "players = 16"
and h1 : "starting_lineup = 10"
and h2 : "goalie = 1"
shows  "n_choose_k (players - goalie) starting_lineup = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A soccer team has 16 players, including 1 goalie. If the starting lineup consists of 10 players, how many different starting lineups can be formed without the goalie? The final answer is 48,048.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes soccer_team starting_lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "soccer_team = 16"
and h1 : "starting_lineup = 11"
shows  "n_choose_k soccer_team starting_lineup = 48048"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My soccer team has 16 players.  I have to choose a starting lineup of a goalie and 10 regular players (the regular players are interchangeable).  How many different starting lineups can I choose? The final Answer is 48,\!048

 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 16 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 10 more players from the remaining 15 players, which is the same as choosing a committee. The answer is \[16\binom{15}{10}=16\binom{15}{5}=16\times\frac{15\times 14\times 13\times 12\times 11}{5\times 4\times 3\times 2\times 1}=\boxed{48,\!048}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes soccer_team starting_lineup :: nat
assumes h0 : "soccer_team = 16"
and h1 : "starting_lineup = 11"
shows  "n_choose_k soccer_team starting_lineup = 48048"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many ways can you choose an 11-player starting lineup from a soccer team of 16 players? The final answer is 48,048.
